title: Deadline to object to discharge under Bankruptcy Code 727(a)(4)
question: The federal rules of bankruptcy procedure, specifically rule 4004(a) makes it seem as though the 60 days deadline to file an adversary proceeding only applies to objections under 727(a)(8) or (a)(9). Can I still file an action to object under 727(a)(4) if the 60 days deadline after the 341(a) hearing has passed?
answers: If you are an individual creditor with a personal debt you want the debtor to repay, you really don't want to file a 727 adversary complaint (which prevents all his debts from being discharged). You want to file a 523 adversary proceeding (which only exempts YOUR debt, but allows the rest of the debts to be discharged, so the debtor has a better ability to pay your debt off). Bankruptcy Rule 4007 governs the time for filing an adversary complaint under 523 and not all subsections require that the complaint be filed within 60 days of the initial 341 meeting. You really should consult with an experienced bankruptcy attorney, both as to grounds and timing of such a complaint.

You should retain the services of a bankruptcy lawyer.

I agree generally with all of the answers you've gotten so far. Every lawyer here will tell you that your analysis is in part correct.

Generally the objection to discharge either pursuant to 727 is 60 days from the date of the INITIAL meeting of creditors, unless the deadline is extended either by stipulation by the debtor as to some creditors, all creditors or the trustee.

If no extension is granted, the deadline is USUALLY but not specifically limited; however the failure to timely file means you are jurisdictionally barred.

However, if a debtor has concealed assets of the estate, the discharge may be revoked. The limit on that is 1 year. However, the 1 year jurisdiction limit is not absolute under limited circumstances. After that you're pretty much out of luck.

You may not be able to object to the discharge but you may bring an adversary proceeding to revoke it.
Also check the docket to see if there has been a stipulation to extend the deadline as that it quite common as well.
There is a deadline - see Rule 4004.

An action under 727(a)4 must be brought within the 60 day period following the 341a meeting (unless an extension is sought before the 60 days are up). Under 727(d) a creditor or the trustee or the US Trustee under limited circumstances can request revocation of a discharge for one year after the case is discharged or closed whichever is later.
A 727 action can be brought within 1 year of the discharge date so it is not too late.
